tn.ref: the twelfth month, which is the month of Adar, on the thirteenth day
tn.text: Translate this as you did a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:est:03:12|3:13]].

tn.ref: when the king's law and decree were about to be carried out
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "when the people were about to carry out the king's law and decree" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: when the king's law and decree were about to be carried out
tn.text: "Carry out" is an idiom meaning do something that was commanded or planned. AT: "when the people were about to obey the king's law and decree" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: to gain power over them
tn.text: Gaining power over people is an idiom for defeating them. AT: "to defeat the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: it was reversed
tn.text: "the situation was reversed." The situation being reversed is a metaphor meaning that the opposite of what was expected happened. AT: "the opposite happened" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: provinces
tn.text: Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:est:01:01|1:1]].

tn.ref: to lay hands on those who tried to bring disaster on them
tn.text: Laying hands on people is a metonym for fight against them. AT: "to fight their enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: who tried to bring disaster on them
tn.text: To bring disaster on people is an idiom meaning to cause a disaster to happen to them. In this case it refers to destroying them. AT: "who tried to destroy them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: No one could stand against them
tn.text: Standing against people represents resisting their attack. AT: "No one could resist the attack of the Jews" or "No one could successfully fight against the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the fear of them had fallen on all the peoples
tn.text: Fear falling on people represents people becoming very afraid. AT: "all the peoples had become very afraid of the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: provincial governors
tn.text: "governors of the provinces"

tn.ref: the fear of Mordecai had fallen on them
tn.text: Fear falling on people represents people becoming afraid. AT: "they had become afraid of Mordecai" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: was great in the king's house
tn.text: "was very important in the king's palace"

tn.ref: his fame spread throughout all the provinces
tn.text: Fame spreading through places represents people in those places learning about how great he was. AT: "throughout the provinces people learned about how great he was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Susa
tn.text: Translate the name of this city as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:est:01:01|1:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: the fortress
tn.text: "the fortified city"

tn.ref: five hundred men
tn.text: "500 men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Parshandatha, Dalphon, Aspatha, Poratha, Adalia, Aridatha, Parmashta, Arisai, Aridai, Vaizatha
tn.text: (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: ten sons
tn.text: "10 sons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Haman
tn.text: Translate this man's name as  you did in [[:en:bible:notes:est:03:01|3:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Hammedatha
tn.text: Translate this man's name as  you did in [[:en:bible:notes:est:03:01|3:1]].(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: the enemy of the Jews
tn.text: This phrase tells us about Haman.

tn.ref: five hundred men
tn.text: "500 men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: ten sons
tn.text: "10 sons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: What then have they done in the rest of the king's provinces?
tn.text: The king uses this question to show that he believes that the Jews must have also killed many people in the other provinces. AT: "What they must have done in the rest of the king's provinces!" or "They must have killed many more in the rest of the king's provinces." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]]

tn.ref: what is your petition
tn.text: The abstract noun "petition" can be expressed with the verb "ask for" or "want"? AT: "What do you ask for?" or "What do you want?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: It will be granted you
tn.text: This can be expressed in active form. AT: "I will give you what you ask for" or "I will do for you what you ask" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: What is your request
tn.text: The abstract noun "request" can be expressed with the verb "ask for" or "want"? AT: "What do you ask for?" or "What do you want?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: to carry out this day's decree tomorrow also
tn.text: "Carry out" is an idiom meaning do something that was commanded or planned. AT: "to obey today's decree tomorrow also" or "to do tomorrow also what was decreed that they should do today" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: ten sons
tn.text: "10 sons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: gallows
tn.text: Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:est:05:14|5:14]].

tn.ref: the fourteenth day of the month of Adar
tn.text: "Adar" is the name of the twelfth and last month of the Hebrew calendar. The fourteenth day is near the beginning of March. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_hebrewmonths]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: laid no hands on the plunder
tn.text: Laying their hands on things represents taking them. AT: "took none of the plunder" or "did not take any of the plunder" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: three hundred
tn.text: "300" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: seventy-five thousand
tn.text: five thousand** - "75,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: they did not lay their hands on the valuables of those they killed
tn.text: Laying their hands on things represents taking them. AT: "they did not take any of the valuables of the people they killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: valuables
tn.text: "things that are valuable" or "possessions"

tn.ref: the thirteenth day of the month of Adar
tn.text: Translate this as you did a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:est:03:12|3:13]].

tn.ref: On the fourteenth day they rested
tn.text: "On the fourteenth day of Adar the Jews who were in the provinces rested"

tn.ref: the Jews who were in Susa assembled together
tn.text: Why they assembled can be stated clearly. AT: "the Jews who were in Susa assembled together to fight against their enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: to keep the fourteenth and the fifteenth day of Adar every year
tn.text: To keep a day is an idiom that means to celebrate it. AT: "to celebrate the fourteenth and fifteenth days of Adar every year" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: their sorrow turned to joy
tn.text: Turning represents changing. The abstract nouns sorry and joy can be expressed with "sad" and "joyful." AT: "they changed from being very sad to being joyful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: This passage summarizes much of the story of Esther in order to explain the reason for the festival of Purim.

tn.ref: Haman son of Hammedatha the Agagite
tn.text: Translated these names as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:est:03:01|3:1]] (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: he threw Pur (that is, he threw lots)
tn.text: "Pur" was the Persian word for "lot." The phrase "he threw lots" explains what "he threw Pur" means.

tn.ref: he threw lots
tn.text: Why he threw lots can be stated clearly. AT: "he threw lots to find out what would be the best day to attack the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: But when the matter came before the king
tn.text: The Hebrew text can also be interpreted to mean, "But when Esther came before the king." Some modern versions choose this interpretation.

tn.ref: the wicked plan Haman developed against the Jews should come back on his own head
tn.text: "Come back on his own head" means that it should be done to Haman. AT: "the wicked plan Haman developed against the Jews should be done to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: they called these days Purim, after the name of Pur
tn.text: To call something after something else is an idiom that means to give it the same name or a similar name. AT: "They called these days Purim, like the word Pur" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Purim
tn.text: This is the  festival that commemorates the salvation of the Jewish people in ancient Persia from Haman's plot to destroy and kill all the Jews in a single day. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: the name of Pur
tn.text: It can be stated clearly what "Pur" means. AT: "the word Pur, which means "lot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: These days were to be celebrated and observed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the Jews were to celebrate and observe these days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: would never cease to faithfully observe
tn.text: This can be stated positively. AT: "would always faithfully observe"

tn.ref: Queen Esther daughter of Abihail and Mordecai the Jew wrote ... this second letter
tn.text: Esther was the daughter of Abihail. Esther and Mordecai wrote the letter.

tn.ref: Abihail
tn.text: Translate this man's name as in [[:en:bible:notes:est:02:15|2:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: second letter
tn.text: "additional letter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Letters were sent to all the Jews
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "They sent letters to all the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: wishing the Jews safety and truth
tn.text: The abstract nouns "safety" and "truth" can be expressed with phrases. AT: "wishing that the Jews would be safe and that people would be faithful to the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: The Jews accepted this obligation for themselves and their descendants
tn.text: Accepting an obligation is a metaphor for agreeing with the obligation. The abstract noun "obligation" can be expressed with the verb "obligate." AT: "The Jews agreed and said that they and their descendants were obligated to celebrate the days of Purim" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: they accepted times of fasting and lamenting
tn.text: Accepting times of fasting and lamenting is a metaphor for agreeing to fast and lament at certain times. AT: "they agreed to fast and lament at certain times [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
